Yes, here are a few examples of how Christians can actively work to prevent persecution:

1. Advocate for religious freedom: Christians can advocate for religious freedom not just for themselves but for all faiths. They can work with local and national organizations to promote religious tolerance and freedom by lobbying governments for constitutional protection of religious liberty and by encouraging dialogues with people of other religions.

2. Speak out against injustice: Christians can speak out against injustice and persecution of any religious, cultural, or ethnic group, and lead the way in promoting peace and justice.

3. Develop strong communities: Christians can develop communities that promote mutual support and care, so that when one member experiences persecution or discrimination, there is a supportive network to help them. They can provide shelter in times of need and offer emotional support to those who are marginalized or persecuted because of their beliefs.

4. Support nonviolent resistance: Christians can engage in nonviolent resistance against persecution, as exemplified by the civil rights movement led by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who advocated for nonviolence and for end of racial discrimination.

5. Build interfaith relationships: Christians can build positive relationships with people of other faiths, by learning and respecting their beliefs, and engaging in dialogue to find common ground. 

By doing these things, Christians can help build a more peaceful society where persecution of religious minorities is minimized or eliminated.
